_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Cytec Industries Inc. - Willow Island Site is providing the 5-year resubmittal of the site's RMP as required under the existing RMP rules as established under 40 CFR 68.

(A.) ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES
Cytec Industries Inc. has established safety, health, emergency response and environmental policies that are in line with applicable local, state and federal regulatory requirements.  Protection of employees and surrounding communities is a integral part of conducting business at the Willow Island, WV site.  Safety is the company's number one core value and is the basis for conducting business at our manufacturing facilities.  Cytec Industries Inc. is a member of the American Chemistry Council (ACC) and subscribes to the ACC's Responsible Care Code.  The Wilow Island site is alsocertifed as a Star Site under OSHA's Voluntary Protection Program (VPP).

(B.) STATIONARY SOURCES AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED
Willow Island's Polymer Additives Business Unit manufactures thiodipropionitrile (TDPN) in a batch process which is used in the production of antioxidants which are used in polyolefins.  The regulated substance which is one of the primary raw materials used in the manufacturing of TDPN is acrylonitrile.

The Polymer Additives Business Unit also manufactures A-1846 which is an intermediate product for the manufacturing of antioxidants used for manufacturing products such as spandex.  The regulated substance s involved with the manufacturing of A-1846 are anhydrous hydrogen chloride and 37% hydrochloric acid.

(C.)  WORST-CASE RELEASE SCENARIO AND ALTERNATIVE RELEASE SCENARIO
As required under the RMP rules Cytec Industries Inc. - Willow Island Site has evaluated a worst case release scenario and alternate release scenarios.

(D.) GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS
The general accidental release prevention program for the Cytec Industries Inc. - Willow Island Site includes;

- USEPA

40 CFR68 - Risk Management Plans
- OSHA 29 CFR 1910.119 - Process Safety Management of Highly Hazardous Chemicals
- OSHA 29 CFR 1910.120 - Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response
- Other USEPA, OSHA, USDOT and state regulations
- Generally recognized and accepted engineering codes and standards
- Cytec Industries Inc. Safety, Health and Environmental Standards

The following is a list of engineering and administrative controls which are intended to prevent the release of anhydrous hydrogen chloride;

- Emergency shutdown systems
- Fire monitors
- Leak detection monitors
- Remote video surveillance monitors
- Excess flow valves
- Caustic scrubber for pipeline venting and purge streams
- Safety interlocks, hard wired in to computer control system
- Tube trailer design to meet USDOT packaging specs for compressed gas
- Piping which meets ASME B31.3 Category M specifications
- Piping which is maintained to API 570 Class 1 specifications

The following is a list of engineering and administrative controls which are intended to prevent the release of acrylonitrile;

- Vapor return system on acrylonitrile unloading station and transfer stations
- Acrylonitrile tank trucks are designed as top-unload
- High level interlock on acrylonitrile storage tank
- Inerting of acrylonitrile storage tank with nitrogen
- Leak, detection and repair program for valves, flanges, and pumps in the acrylonitrile system
- Formal inspection program which involves non-destructive testing including ultrasonic thickness testing, on the storage tank and piping

The following is a list of engineering and administrative controls which are intended to prevent the release of 37% hydrochloric acid;

- Vapor return system for hydrochloric acid unloading and transfer operations
- Hydrochloric acid trucks are designed as top-unload
- Storage tanks have not side or bottom outlets for transfers
- High level interlock on hydrochloric acid tanks
- Hydrochloric acid storage tanks are vented through a s

crubber system 
- Hydrochloric acid storage tank is subject to non-destructive testing to ensure integrity

(E.) 5-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
Since the last submittal of the site's RMP (September 28, 2000) there have been no incidnets which meet the reporting requirements for the 5-year accident history.

(F.) EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM
The Cytec Industries Inc. - Willow Island site has an emergency response program which includes a written Emergency Operations Manual and active emergency response team and fire brigade.  The site's emergency response program outlines actions to be taken by operating business units, maintenance, utilities, administrative personnel and emergency response personnel.  In addition the site's plan also includes requirements for site visitors and contractors.  The site's fire brigade and emergency response team also conduct internal drills in addition to drills with outside response agencies (i.e. local fire departments).

(G.) PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY
The Willow Island facility strives for continuous improvement and utilizes new control technologies, employee training, process upgrades, inspections, and repair and maintenance of equipment in order to improve safety, health and environmental performance.
